name: LG WH14NS40 Blu-Ray/DVD/CD Writer
comments: it's a Blu-ray disk reader.

I've had bad luck with LG in the past with a Blu-ray player, but this one is holding up well so far and it's priced very well for an internal Blu-ray drive. As another reviewer mentioned, it makes a click-buzz sound on startup, reminiscent of old PCs from the '90s and early 2000s, but besides that, I found it very quiet and making almost no vibration, even when with high disc spin speeds (though part of it may also be due to the case).
Not too many ppl use optical drives anymore, I bought this over 8 years ago and it still works like new. Use it to rip and play all my DVDs
Not too many ppl use optical drives anymore, I bought this over 8 years ago and it still works like new. Use it to rip and play all my DVDs.
I actually like how this is put together. It's the one 5.25" addon I have hooked up.
Works out of the box with no setup or bloatware. Blu-Rays require extra libraries, but that's a software problem that goes outside the scope of this review; bottom line is, it does what it needs to.

Cheapest and best Blu-ray disc bay I could find at the time.
It burns and reads all formats (cd, DVD, Blu-ray) works fine based on my testing, the only complaint I have is that it's a bit stiff and rough when opening and closing, so make sure your discs are in completely and correctly!
Good price and good performance. I use it almost everyday with working with CD's.
Works fine. Makes a charming click-buzz on startup, I love it.
Works good and I can also watch Blue-ray and do Disc burning!

name: Asus BW-16D1HT Blu-Ray/DVD/CD Writer
comments: Have been using this to rip data files from CD's and DVD's. Works well for playing Blu-Ray media too.
Works very well. Not too noisy while playing DVDs.
This drive is very fast and is compatible with Blu-Ray however, it is quite loud, so keep that in mind.

Highly recommended by disc preservation communities, for good reason.
Side note: The tray actuation on this drive is anything but quiet.
Rips Blu-Rays, quickly. Doesn't make too much noise. No complaints. Additionally, new firmware can be flashed to support 4K ripping.
Man this thing is loud. Great for MakeMKV compatibility, but it is far and away the loudest component in the computer.
Great! Does what I need it to!

The Asus BW-16D1HT Blu-Ray/DVD/CD Writer runs fast and was easy to install. Read and write speeds are far above average. I got this mainly for the M-Disc technology which I plan to use one day. I haven't had any problems with it so far and it seems to be a excellent optical drive.
Paying for the name but still a good quality drive that works for my movie buffs that still use DVDs
Once again, I don't use this very much, but it's quite reliable and fast when I do use it.

name: Lite-On iHAS124-14 DVD/CD Writer
comments: i have used this 2 times and the 2 times i have used it worked great
Cheap and it works. Cost has almost doubled in the past few years though.
Goes at around 2-4MB/s, just needed it to read some cd's, took 30 minutes, but for not having to use it constantly it is completely fine and works well. Closes when pushing the tray.
This helps me install windows 10 home in 2016. Today (2023) it still works
It Reads CD'S
It worked for a while, but then it stopped opening properly. It was like this ever since the first time I opened the disc tray.
Does the job
LiteOn and ASUS are the only ones still making optical drives, it seems.
Not plugged in because the gpu blocks half the SATA ports. But I did test it, and it works.

It has one job, which it does without making too much noise. That makes it worth of a thumbs-up in my book. It's the first optical drive I've used where you can't just push in the tray to make it close, but whatever. It's cheap and it works.

name: Asus DRW-24B1ST/BLK/B/AS DVD/CD Writer
comments: Not quite as fast as a disc drive from a 2008 Dell... so yeah, what's up with that? EAC prefers to use the Dell. Other than that, it's perfectly fine.

Extremely loud, though this might just be how optical drives generally were (i haven't used one in a desktop in over a decade), also surprisingly noisy at idle if there's a disk inside not actively being used. I do also wish these manufacturers could at least black out the exterior on modern examples. These REALLY stick out in even remotely modern systems.
That sure is a Disc Drive! It rips CDs, it plays my music, there's nothing else I need. A+.
Simple DVD reader/writer. No bells or whistles. Just a DVD reader/writer. Reasonable price.
It's an optical disk drive. There's not much to say about it. It does make an odd noise when the PC is powered on, but it's not loud or anything.
Re-using old parts from 4+ years ago.
Got this as a joke for my build. Works well actually and is a pretty solid DVD drive.
why not? the drive works, reads, probably writes, I haven't checked. it does make an odd noise when the pc is turned on, or when the drive is closed, but it doesn't bother me.
Great for burning media, and lets me write cd's for my radio.

name: Pioneer BDR-S13UBK DVD Reader, Blu-Ray/CD Writer
LG WH16NS40 Blu-Ray/DVD/CD Writer
comments: Did not come with one of the required cables, but otherwise, it's an optical drive. it rips CDs, installs old games, plays movies, all that good stuff. I don't really know what to say other than that.
It's fun to open and close.
It plays CDs, DVDs, and Blu-rays: exactly what I bought it for because I like owning my media and not renting it from streaming services.

It plays blu-rays and DVDs and HD discs. It does need the right software but it does do those things.
My wife doesn't particularly need this but even long after my wife upgrades to a completely new computer in the future, I can instead use the computer as a media center for my blu-rays, DVDs, and emulated gaming thanks to this thing.
Works as advertised.

I don't think you really need a disc drive in your pc nowadays, and there are some decent usb externals that probably do the job. I've never had a problem with this one though, and its been a little above-average at reading some 'rough' discs that other readers had trouble with.
I have a large collection of old discs full of games, apps, music and whatever kicking around, and its nice to be able to plug them in, and copy what I want to save.

Does what it's supposed to...
Though, adding to that: "Playing BluRay Movies" is not something it's supposed to do sadly (which was my mistake).
It can write to BluRay storage media (as in discs), but it doesn't magically come with the software and encoders (or whatever they're called) to read the BluRay movies. Blame DMCA and the greedy film industry for trying to undo as much of the Betamax case ruling as possible in the name of "fighting Piracy".
So if you ever see "DVD on BluRay", it'll now make sense to you.
A great selection if you're looking for a device capable of R/W to multiple disc formats.
This is a standard Blu-Ray writer. It does a good job. Old technology, should be perfected by now, and it is. Made by a reliable company.
Not much to say. It plays my Blurays and games. Quiet when its working. Does what it was built to do.
Great drive. Perfect for CD, DVD, and Blu-ray nerds like me. Haven't even used all its features yet, like M-Disc. Works great for ripping and burning discs. No problems ever.

name: Asus DRW-24F1ST DVD/CD Writer
comments: I wanted to just be able to write "CD drive. It works" and put 5 stars but I just can't. It is a CD drive that does work but it makes an absolutely irritating noise on startup. After that it is silent though.
Functional.
A welcome part of any PC, solidly built and works for all my CDs so far.
Does it's job for when you need a CD for some reason. (If that is ever anymore)
Its better to have a optical drive and not need it, then to need it and not have it.
Works amazing is a little loud but was 20 dollars so cant complain.
Can't complain - for the price! Loaded Windows with no issues. Seems to work as expected. Little bit loud, but again, for the price...
It does what it needs to, is relatively quiet while it does so, and only one of the two I bought lit on fire. What more can you ask?
Does the job well. Poor packaging.
works great fast not to loud

name: Pioneer BDR-212DBK Blu-Ray/DVD/CD Writer
comments: It does its job.

name: Asus DRW-24D5MT DVD/CD Writer
comments: Loud and annoying startup noises
Doesn’t really work with TrueNAS but in my other system it makes an annoying sound when booting so I pulled it out
It works, a little noisy at first, but that isn't a problem for what I use it for.
It makes anoying noise when booting. But works. Ye, nothing more. The noise is damn bad because I tried to make silent system.
Loud but gets the job done.
It's bulky but that's my only very minor complaint, does the job well
Wanted two Optical Drives. This ordinary CD/DVD Drive was better for CDs.

It works, but jaysus lawd it’s like Formula One when it’s running - not in terms of speed but in terms of noise.
Mind that it does NOT come with any SATA cables.
It also comes with a DVD full of drivers and probably other garbage, but there’s no need for this since it’s pretty much plug and play.
Perfect for occasional usage.
Does what I need it to do
One of best DVD burners I've had, I currently shift it from PC to PC with a USB adapter as other LG drives fail and this one plods on ever faithful

name: Panasonic UJ-265 Blu-Ray/DVD/CD Writer
comments: Its a drive and it works that is all
Worked fine. Packaging could use some work. Needs the adapter to work.

name: Pioneer BDR-209DBK Blu-Ray/DVD/CD Writer
comments: This component was the whole point of building my own design.

It's alright! Haven't extensively tested its' read/write speeds but this doesn't make much noise other than the sector search noise as is common with most disc players when reading a disc. This was much better than my previous god-knows-what-make-it-was DVD writer, which made an annoying sound that made it sound like I had kicked my PC when I started up my PC???

Being a little old-school I did generally only buy this for its capabilities of reading/writing and for the install of windows 10 & any games I have on disk from the old PC's. The drive itself is quiet but I've yet to test out its writing speeds.
Bonus in itx build. Space it occupies raises temps a little. Some sector search noise common to disk players e.g. in malware scan.
A great drive for older games I had, as well as CDs and Blu Rays. I did wish it came with some sort of Blu-Ray software. That stuff can get expensive!

It's a great Bluray/DVD/CD writer. I bought it because of its low price. I was surprised that it performed so well! I've burned about 10 Bluray discs already and I encountered no issues at all. All my writes were perfect! It's a pretty fast writer too. I've also used it to write DVDs. Works great as well! This can also write on LTH Bluray Discs, which are the cheaper, more affordable Bluray discs. Just take note that some Bluray players are unable to read LTH Bluray discs. This optical drive is also a quiet drive. I noticed that the noise it generates is coming from the discs being used. Some discs seem to be noisier than others. So far all of my discs I've burned are quiet. I would highly recommend this Optical drive due to its capabilities and low price.
Works good, reasonably priced. Picked because of the all black face which looks great compared to the black drives with white text.
It's a Blu-Ray Drive! Plays blu-rays despite Windows's best efforts not to. Haven't tried writing disks yet.
Ordered from Newegg. Installed my Windows DVD without a hitch. Will update after I have a chance to try out some burns.

One of my first burners was a Pioneer back in the day so I thought, why not? I had to paint this drive. No drive comes black and it looks like crap inside the case otherwise. Some Krylon and masking tape saved the day. Obviously this voids the warranty, but I think you'll agree it's worth it.

name: Asus BC-12D2HT Blu-Ray/DVD/CD Writer
comments: Yeah, I made a new build in 2024 with an optical drive of all things, and one that supports Blu-ray, even.
You can use this for reading PS3's game disc!
Very fast and quiet.
Great for ripping Blu-Rays with MakeMKV
bought to see bluray movies, it works fine if you have the proper software!

Nice and quiet when running games/ dvd's, I can confirm that it plays CD, DVD and blu ray. When burning it is not that noisy either (when compared to a dell one) and the 6gb/s interface makes reading discs nice and speedy. Easy to use and reliable
quick and quiet

name: LG GH24NSD1 DVD/CD Writer
comments: Affordable, quality unit (though there was some clicking coming from the drive). Could install Windows 10 with no issues
This Optical Drive does what it should and is also pretty quick at reading Discs only negative part is the loudness on active Reading and Writing.
It's ok.
The two optical drives are overkill, but I just thought they would look nice in the drive trays on top. They are working fine for me so far.
Not so much to say here, it doesn't look any good TBH but I don't really care since I haven't bought it for its aspect (the front panel of my case does its job hiding it as it's supposed to do).

Sticks a bit when it slides out. Bit noisy. Would use an external DVD drive in future as the cost is not much higher and it cleans up the build.
I can't understand how people do without an optical completely though - I always need to load the mobo drivers to get the network up and running.
Just using it sometimes no problems.
A simple DVD writer. Bought cause the case had the ODD slot :D
Trusted Brand, Best performance in this range of burners.
There is never really much to say about these.

name: LG GH24NSD5 DVD/CD Writer
comments: It's a DVD drive and it functions. Can't really say anything else about it.
It's broken now.
A bit on the loud side, but for 12€, I can't complain too much.

name: LG BH16NS55.AUAR10B Blu-Ray/DVD/CD Writer
comments: A great blu-ray drive, especially once you flash it to enable its 4k/UHD features.

Can be loud under certain situations! Do Not Buy the combo with the Cyberpower software! Was a rip-off!! I was unable to play a blue ray disc to test if it was working, even after installing the Cyberpower package! Ended up having to purchase the blue ray software separately in order to play the movie! But it can read/write/rr M-Discs so that’s a plus. Just don’t get the drive with the software bundle!

Probably my main disappointment as I forgot about licencing and software for this. Works OK as a burner in Windows but will likely need a copy of PowerDVD or similar to be able to play my library of Blu-ray discs. The unit itself is solid and will no doubt give plenty of years of service.

name: LG BU40N Blu-Ray/DVD/CD Writer
comments: It works well, plays 4K blu-ray in VLC with firmware flash and makemkv.

name: LG GH24NSC0 DVD/CD Writer
comments: Years old, still going strong! I have an elderly friend with a huge CD collection he shares with me, so I'm frequently importing CDs.
It's a DVD drive, that's it
The just cheap best deal, no problem with it.

DVD RW + M-DISC functionality.
Update: Stopped working properly and only opens CDs, no DVD functionality whatsoever. Should have checked the negative reviews on the official LG website before buying:
https://www.lg.com/us/burners-drives/lg-GH24NSC0-internal-dvd-drive/reviews
It's an optical drive. It makes noise when it needs to and reads discs. It didn't cost much, either. Pretty cool.
Its a cost effective solution if you want or need an optical drive.
Just a simple DVD drive for Windows and drivers, possibly some movies.
It works, what else can I say?
its a cd writer... what more is there to say
a little loud, but does it job

name: LG WH16NS60 Blu-Ray/DVD/CD Writer
comments:
With the right software you can read, write, and play CDs, BDs, DVDs, and 3DBDs.
Unfortunately, I can't play commercial UHD discs, but it's not its fault.
Needs firmware flash to rip 4k blu rays

I'd imagine this would be great at playing Blu-rays. I say I imagine, because due to some proprietary DRM ******** called the Protected Audio/Video Pipeline that all Blu-rays require for playback on PC, it's completely impossible to directly play back Blu-rays unless you are using an Intel CPU with integrated graphics. If you have an Intel F-series or an AMD CPU, these TV/film studios could not care less about you as the customer. Because of this, I unfortunately wasted money buying this thing, as I myself have a Ryzen 9 5900X.
But despite all that said, this drive is super quiet in operation and makes no vibrations, making it pretty much perfect for watching DVDs or playing back CDs, even in a relatively quiet room. It's also as good of a burner/ripper as it gets--and amusingly, Blu-ray rippers still work despite my predicament, meaning that in a hilariously ironic twist, this DRM was there to stop me from doing "illegal" things to the discs has instead forced me to.
Anyway, if you're running any AMD or Intel F-series CPU, then don't buy this if you're looking to watch any movies or TV shows straight off the disc with it. But if you wanna burn your own BD-Rs, or rip those aforementioned BDs/UHD-BDs, then go right ahead.

9) LG - WH16NS60 Blu-Ray/DVD/CD Writer
BluRay writer that I copped from my previous build. Its new purpose does not need an optical drive, and if it ever does I will just use a USB optical drive.

name: LG GH24NSC0B DVD/CD Writer
comments: This is about as basic as DVD-RW drives get, but it works perfectly, so if you still use discs, there you go.
Still inside my pre-built, works well when used, which is almost never. These have kind of become obsolete, but can't complain of it's efficacy over the years when it was useful.
It's a DVD drive. IDK what to say about it. Works.

Un peu inutile en 2019 mais toujours utile d'en avoir un sous la main. Par exemple, plusieurs fabricants de composantes mettent les logiciels et driver sur le cd, il n'y a donc pas besoin d'aller les télécharger sur internet, surtout quand on a une connexion d'à peine 3 mégaoctet par secondes. (pas la fibre optique dans mon secteur et actuellement, les forfaits en fibres optiques coûtent trop cher.)
OK
I could have left an optical drive off the build but I thought it'd be nice to have. Haven't used it yet but looks like it's working fine.
It's a disk drive. It has a black front for a bit more sleekness. It makes more noise than I'd like to hear.
Haven't really used it yet!
Loud but for the price I can't complain too much. The customer likes to still burn CDs and watch movies.
Cheep but works well.

name: LG GS40N DVD/CD Writer
comments: It's a DVD drive. It reads and writes DVDs and CDs. It works. No complaints.

The DVD writer obviously fits my Raven RZV02B HTPC case, but the front plate is a bit thin, leaving a 2 mm gap on the left of it. It doesn't hurt (as long as you don't lose a DVD in it), but it's a bit ungainly. If you're OCD, you might want to look at the front plate width in detail, or go with an external unit.
It works, it reads it writes whatever requires odd slimline sata to sata with power cable attachment...
About the only affordable slim drive on the market, you will have to buy the slim to full sata adapter separately, but since the next one up is $80+ for DvD or $150 blu-ray its a fine choice.

name: LG GH24NSB0 DVD/CD Writer
comments: still does his job whenever a new farming simulator comes out
At the moment of writing, i have got errors while trying to burn DVDs. I'll expect to change it soon.
Just a generic DVD writer. I had a choice of lots of brands, but I got LG because of their quality.

Very noisy, and a bit overpriced, but I needed it in a pinch and it was the cheapest thing at Best Buy. It does its job and would be a good deal for maybe $10 less, but for $30 I'd like it to be a little quieter. I shouldn't wake up my friends when they're sleeping a room over.
It's a DVD drive. You'll need one eventually. Quiet loud, but do you know of a disc drive that isn't? No? Buy the cheapest one unless you need blu-ray.
It works, not the fastest but gets the job done.
Acquired from local PC repair/electronics shop. Used for installing older games from CD/DVD and for watching movies, documentaries, storing data on DVDs. Does what it's supposed to.
Cant say nothing bad, other than slightly unbalanced.
Works just as it should so I'm happy.
It's a DVD/CD writer

name: LG BH16NS40 Blu-Ray/DVD/CD Writer
comments: was cheap and writes discs reasonably fast, just wish it was bit faster when booting off it when I do use it for that.

For as long as I've had it, it worked beautifully. However, as the PC meta changes, so do cases. Now it's being barely used and collecting dust on my desk, plugged in externally via a SATA to USB 3.0 adapter. Otherwise, it's a good product.
Works
Makes a very loud sound on boot up or whenever it reads discs.
Works great, not a fan of some of the software that comes with it. I opted to not install some of it.
Awesome, burns and plays every type of media cd/dvd/bd you can think off. Great for watch movies and burning backup files onto disc
Works.

name: Samsung SH-224DB/BEBE DVD/CD Writer
comments: Works fine
Well, it's a relic from the past but the only way to access some data that would be lost otherwise. It does it's job flawlessly and it's been reliable even with almost no use at all.
Who uses cd-DVD nowadays? Me. Excellent price-value ratio.
Does the job. Call me a boomer, but I love me some DVDs/CDs sorry
For the very few times that I used it, it has worked well. However, the technology has become obsolete and I only keep it in the case to cover the hole that would be left by it.

Does its job, and price was right. And yes, I am actually using this to archive a bunch of old TV shows and movies from DVDs using Handbrake. Works great -- I stream directly to TV over WiFi using VLC Media Player.
Pretty good unit.
Hasn't let me down when i use it.
Pretty standard optical drive, isn't too loud, can read and write DVD/CDs fine, no Blu-ray functionality though.
Works, no reason it shouldn't. Nothing bad to say about it. Some people don't have an optical drive in their PC, great thing is they are cheaper than a pizza if you need one for some reason.

name: Asus BW-12B1ST/BLK/G/AS Blu-Ray/DVD/CD Writer
comments: Great Optical Drive! It gets a bit loud when ripping and writing.
A good blue ray player, though one should note that it does not come with any blue ray playing software, and VLC does not support blue rays yet, at least last I checked.
The CD/DVD Drive is loud when actively working, yes. However, it is damn fast at burning/ripping data to and from discs.
Who doesn't still have some retro game that they need to install on optical? Am I right?
I probably spent too much on this but it reads blu rays and zoo tycoon like a champ.

This Blue Ray has been used in 3 computers so far. No problems, Plug-n-Play worked every time. Some people complain that it doesn't play Blue ray straight out of the box. That is a software thing, not the player. You need a 3rd party decoder for Blue ray.
Got it for burning Blu-Rays, haven't done a single one. 5/5
Works great, but is loud while reading discs.
Works great but a faster write speed is needed.
Good solid drive, haven't had a lot of oppertunity to try out all functions yet but so far it's fast and doesn't spool up like a 747

It works.
This is just a cheapo dvd burner nothing ,more nothing less

It's an optical drive. It works fine. I just got it for any driver disks that I might need to install; that or any old games on disks that I want to play. I just couldn't convince myself that not getting one would have been a good choice.

Great
Bought this Blu-Ray optical drive a good while ago, love this thing for burning CD's, DVD's and occasionally Blu-Ray's.

Got this drive because it was cheap for a Blu Ray drive. I bought it for driver installs, Blu Ray movies, and games based off of CDs (I own a few). It works good, and reads quick enough. It also blends well with my case.
It plays blu-rays and DVD's... Don't know what else to say about it except I kind of wish I would of gotten one that was a little faster with reading.

This is a cheap but effective BD reader. Normally I wouldn’t have anything special to say about an optical drive. However, this one is very quiet. The only time I’ve heard it making a significant amount of noise is when burning a standard audio CD at its fastest speed.

name: Pioneer BDC-207DBK Blu-Ray Reader, DVD/CD Writer
comments: LOL, I bought an optical drive way back in 2013 on my first build. What a rookie move. I barely used the thing, and I bought a blu ray drive specifically to watch movies. Another mistake, since you have to purchase driver software for exorbitant rates to even run a blu ray disc. It's a racket and I surely won't be buying another. I took it out of the case for a few years, but I put it in since I wasn't using it for anything else. It's still in the case, collecting dust.

It reads and writes DVDs as expected, but every time my PC comes out of standby mode or powers up the optical drive does a spin up thing that seems unnecessary. Perhaps its some kind of power saving "E-Green" thing on the front of the drive? Its a great value, but you get what you pay for.
I like the little motor rev sound it makes when the PC boots? IDK what to say about it, it's just a generic DVD drive.
Rarely used, but still comes in handy for some old games and programs I have floating around.

No complaints, it operates without issues and it sits completely flush with the front of the case.
Decent and working CD Writer.

name: Samsung SH-222BB/BEBE DVD/CD Writer
comments: Haven't used it yet except to load software and drivers. Lookikng forward to trying a BuleRay movie.
Nothing special, picked it up at hard drives northwest for quite cheap. Only going to use it a few times, and it hurts the aesthetic of the case, so might pull it out sometime soon.

name: LG GH24NS95 DVD/CD Writer
comments: It can read and burn cds decently, mine rattles but its also oldish
I still burn CD's for my car, maybe I am a bit old.
Wanted something to be behind the hidden front door when opened :) Will likely make a great cup holder...
Unlike the picture the branding of this drive is actually black, which is far better looking! I know we are using these less and less but I think it's still good to have in systems for now.
Maybe it was from the delivery but was very loud, going to replace at local PC store.
It's an optical drive. I don't think it's going to stay in this build much longer; I never use it.
Never had a problem.
It works lol

name: LG GH24NSB0B DVD/CD Writer
comments: Not much to say about it. It reads CDs and DVDs. Its slow and loud like just about all CD drives. Probably why no one uses these anymore lol.
its lg so should be a quality product but it does get a little loud when loading something up. besides the noise it does its job well and its lg so i like it.

Cheap, but sturdy. In retrospect, I have a TON of these laying around collecting dust. Ordering a new one was pointless. If anything I should have ordered a bluray drive instead, as my only current bluray option is a Playstation that my GF uses constantly.
LG is a good brand. I've never had one go out on me. If you need a disc drive for whatever reason, they're acceptable. Mine was necessary because I had drivers to install to get internet access to install drivers for the rest of the PC. If you already have a PC, you can get the drivers on a thumb drive and use that to transfer them. If you don't have a PC, a disc drive is actually quite handy for getting started.

name: Pioneer BDR-212EBK Blu-Ray Reader, DVD/CD Writer
Asus DVD-E818AAT/BLK/B/GEN DVD/CD Drive
comments: Got windows onto my Computer fine a bit slow for my taste though.

name: LG BT30N Blu-Ray/DVD/CD Writer
comments: Reads, writes (and plays with the additional software I purchased) Blurays. DVDs etc. A little pricier than the cheapest external, but it looks nice and is quiet.

name: HP DVD1265I DVD/CD Writer
comments: Part is as advertised, but the noise level was a little disappointing.
It works

Leftover from an older build. My family and I still use some older software and a lot of our older pictures/home movies are burned to CDs and DVDs. That, and when the kids visit for longer periods of time, they sometimes like to watch movies by themselves (or vice-versa).
Speedy opens and closes! Sweet!
I mean, it opens smooth, reads CDs and DVDs and stuff. What more can you ask for? I hardly use it, but I prefer to have it just in case.

Not sure I picked the right model. I like it because it has LightScribe, which my photo clients like because I can laser etch their cover shots into the CDRs. Neat! I also have a 'yuge CD collection that I'm spending half my life ripping to HDD. I know I'm a dinosaur for liking optical drives but I don't know how the rest of you are living without them!
Works. Is very loud though.
HP 18x DVD Writer for those pesky game discs.

name: LG UH12NS40 Blu-Ray Reader, DVD/CD Writer
comments:
Great Blu-Ray player, not so great at reading DVDs.
It'll do just fine playing a DVD to watch video, but if you are trying to rip DVDs or data, it only reads at 12x speed - my 10 year old HP reads at 48x. I was pretty disappointed. Otherwise, this is a good drive for all other purposes.
Does what it says on the tin, fair warning you need paid software to actually play a Blu-Ray disc, the codec isn't free like DVD and CD.
She wanted a CD-Drive. Found this on a Newegg flash sale. Boom.
Bought it on a deep sale and works as intended. Finding an application to play BR movies for free is the biggest pain about it though.

Probably could have gone without a blu-ray drive but as near 40 year old I have a ton of physical media & I still prefer to buy physical copies of music, games and movies when I can. The drive itself is great. It's fast, like really fast ripping media & quiet. Can't ask for more than that.
Works fine, but no software. I knew that, I just didn't know how much of a pain it was to get a PC BR player working. I think I use Leawo.

name: Samsung SN-208FB/BEBE DVD/CD Writer
comments:
It came without any screw and I had a hard time attaching it to my case. (But it works...)
If you are inventive, you too, you will find a way to attach it to your case... (Personally, I used foil tape... :-/)

name: Asus BC-12B1ST/BLK/B/AS Blu-Ray Reader, DVD/CD Writer
comments: Old drive that is likely ~10-12 years old but still works fine.

I needed an optical drive at the time of my 2013 build and this was one of the best around. I had no issues with it ever other than trying to get the Blu-Ray to play properly, but that was more an issue of software than one of hardware. I eventually pulled it out of the build in 2018 as I no longer had need of it.
just a standard blu ray player works fine as intended
works great.
Works like it should. Blu-Ray movie nights everyday!
Fast read and write speeds!
Does what I need it to for ripping blurays and DVDs to my Plex server. Externalized it once I had no more space
Will eventually need a Blu-Ray Writer.
It reads disks and burns them. What more can you want?
Installed windows. 10/10

name: Samsung SH-B123L/RSBP Blu-Ray Reader, DVD/CD Writer
comments: Hold over from 2011 build. Still running and easy to install. Still salty it doesn't include software to watch blu rays.
Hard to install and didn't come with software like I thought it would.
Was given to me for free and works fine

name: LG BH14NS40 Blu-Ray/DVD/CD Writer
comments: It's an optical drive. I am not sure many of the current generation builders know what "CD's" are, but back in the late 80's and early 90's they were huge. With the adoption of the personal PC you could transfer the audio tracks from these CD's and put them on your Hard Drive. Your parents would hate you for filling up their 500MB hard drive with a half dozen CDs. Yes I am a dinosaur. Yes I still like having an optical. There is a rare occasion I will put in a movie that I don't have a digital code too.

name: LG UH12NS29 Blu-Ray Reader, DVD/CD Writer
comments: Got it hoping to be able to play 4k Blurays on it.... I'm hoping somebody comes through on this front. It can read the discs but currently there's no player out. PowerDVD might be the first here soon

name: Sony AD-7260S-0B DVD/CD Writer
comments: An old CD/DVD drive from another build. It's noisy, but works when needed. I also like that it has an all-black front panel, works well with the case aesthetic

name: Lite-On iHOS104-06 Blu-Ray/DVD/CD Drive
comments: Just in case I wanted to watch a Blu-Ray disc on my PC.

name: Lite-On iHAS224-06 DVD/CD Writer
comments: still works.
Not exact to what I have but it's a basic drive, quiet for one too.

name: Lite-On iHDP118-04 DVD/CD Drive
comments: basically exactly like the ODD i reviewed above BUT it's really loud when it turns on for whatever reason lol

name: LG WH12LS30 Blu-Ray/DVD/CD Writer
comments: It reads, it writes, it's cheap, what more do you want? Has been in my computer tower for 12 years and is doing great.

name: Samsung SH-224BB DVD/CD Writer
comments: Don't use it anymore lol.

For when you absolutely cannot avoid using an optical drive. Build quality is okay (could be better), functionality and compatibility has been fine, haven't had any major problems. For the price, it's not a bad deal.
The only reason why this loses a star is because of the lack of native blu-ray codec support. Otherwise, it was a decision that I made to keep this drive, and utilize it.
I wanted to add a cheap but quality DVD/CD writer. I have used Samsung drives in the past and never had any issues. Samsung offers a good warranty.

I was a little worried this wouldn't function correctly as it sounded like something in it was rattling when I got it in the mail, but after powering up for the first time it worked perfectly and exceeded my expectations. It is capable of reading and writing all but blu-ray disk media and it is as fast as a whip for its price. Had no qualms installing all my older disk-based games and the drivers disks for the hardware were installed in a flash. It blends in very well with the case too, adding a nice touch to the aesthetic of the front. My only complaint is that it is nosier than expected, but its still quiet enough for the speed it runs at.
Works very well, but seems rather loud when it spools up.
